Comment: This is not the case.  Congress cannot declare a strike *illegal*. To do so would violate both the 1st and 13th Amendments. When you make something illegal, you're imposing criminal sanctions on it.  What Congress did was declare a strike *unlawful*. What this means is that while the rail workers are free to refuse to work (and to collectively make a decision about that), they will not receive the protections afforded by labor law if they do so. The main protections are that, in a lawful strike, your employer cannot fire you or (in some cases) permanently replace you.

Comment: It's the kind of distinction journalists miss but the Department of Labor pays close attention to.  In practice, declaring an strike unlawful makes it unlikely to ever occur. An unlawful strike is the equivalent of walking into your boss's office, declaring "I quit!" and then adding a list of ways your boss can convince you to come back to work. In most cases, your boss would simply hire someone else to replace you.
